bibl.title: Letter from Ross A. McFarland to Philip Showalter Hench, August 13, 1948

div1.p: McFarland has been unable to obtain the aerial photograph that Hench requested, but will ask Pan American Airways to take one for him.

div1.head: Letter from Ross A. McFarland to Philip Showalter Hench, August 13, 1948
div1.opener:
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
GRADUATE SCHOOL OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION
GEORGE F. BAKER FOUNDATION
SOLDIERS FIELD
BOSTON 63, MASSACHUSETTS
August 13, 1948
DIVISION OF RESEARCH
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am very sorry indeed that there has been such a long
delay in acknowledging your letter of May 6th along with the enclosure
of your article entitled “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. I was
delighted with this lecture and shall prize it very highly indeed.

I wonder if you have had anymore success in obtaining the
photograph which you wished to use showing the suburb of Havana.
We have been unable to find a suitable one for you in the Pan
American Airways System. I have canvassed all of the different
possibilities and no suitable photographs are available. As a
final attempt I am sending the map of Havana and the sketch which
you sent to me to the local manager of PAA in Havana to see if it
would be possible for him to have one taken from the air for you.
I have asked him to write to you direct so I hope you will hear
from him before very long.

Did you have any success with the American Geographical
Society in New York? I was surprised at what you said in your
letter about the noncooperative attitude of the National Geographical
Society. As a matter of fact, I have just been obtaining some
photographs for them and they seemed very ready to be on the receiv-
ing side. Mr. F. Barrows Colton of their editorial staff is pre-
paring an article on the possibility of spreading disease by aircraft
or something of the like. In case you wish to have any further
correspondence with anyone at the National Geographical Society, I
suggest that you correspond with him. He might be more sympathetic
with your present project.
With best wishes to you and Jan Tillisch, I am
